content:
This is admittedly not a dev tools topic but starting here in the hopes someone can point me in the right direction because i'm not sure where to ask.

I saw an email earlier that went out to leads which referenced a prior mail that I gather was sent to all@rust-lang.org (or something to that effect). However, I did not receive that other email and it reminded me of past occasions where emails were alluded to but which I also did not receive.

So the question, is there indeed such an "everyone" DL, and if so does it really include everyone/am I not receiving some communications? I'm wondering if perhaps the team vs. working group distinction could be a factor as well given that rustfmt is a WG

You are correct that all does not include working groups.

It's not really clear to me why rustfmt and rustup are "working groups". I always associate that with a group working towards some specific goal, not ongoing maintenance and development.

Eric Huss said:

You are correct that all does not include working groups.

It's not really clear to me why rustfmt and rustup are "working groups". I always associate that with a group working towards some specific goal, not ongoing maintenance and development.

Ah, that helps thank you. I've always felt fuzzy on the differences between the teams vs wgs given some of the working groups that are out there (including rustup and rustfmt). If that's indeed an intended distinction, with wgs being more comparatively short term, with a finitely scoped set of objectives, then having rustup and rustfmt as wgs seems quite odd/wrong indeed

The only definition I'm aware of is alluded to in RFC 2856. However, I don't think it is well defined.

For example, an IETF working group is defined by:

Working groups are typically created to address a specific problem or to produce one or more specific deliverables (a guideline, standards specification, etc.). Working groups are generally expected to be short-lived in nature. Upon completion of its goals and achievement of its objectives, the working group is terminated.

The wiki definition also alludes to it being goal-oriented and finite duration.
ha yeah, i think rustfmt and rustup are quite a poor fit for that definition
What IETF calls working groups we call project groups I believe.

regardless of terminology, something about the current state of affairs feels wrong to me, as folks on the rustup and rustfmt <<insert preferred term for group of people>> are not receiving communications they arguably should be, except in cases where individuals also happen to be a member of some other "team".

i believe something should change, whether that means we need to convert working groups to teams, or somehow expand the list of who is included, or something else
@Daniel Silverstone @Manish Goregaokar curious what your thoughts are on this
I do think rustfmt and rustup should both just be part of devtools as subteams, alongside Cargo; I think that makes sense.
Given I have no idea what I may have missed, I'm not sure what to say. I do receive all@ mail though as well as leads@ - are we talking about something else?
@Daniel Silverstone You are a member of the "devtools" team, that's how you get "all".

Right. So @Daniel Silverstone I think it's more a question of, do you think rustup folks should be recieving all@ comms/how would you feel if you weren't receiving them? I'd guess rbtcollins is in a similar boat as me, seeing leads@ but not any of the all@ and hi-rustin isn't receiving anything (assuming neither of them are also members of other proper teams like you are w/devtools)

I'd say 95% of what I receive via all@ is spam, which isn't a terribly useful metric, but it's the truth. It's hard to say whether I'd be sad not getting it because I appear to have received only six or seven emails via it which still remain in my archive since the start of 2020.

If I were to express any opinion it'd be that all@ is a bad alias name and we should drop it entirely. If we have role/team-membership aliases only, then people would be able to work out who they want to email by those and send it to two or three addresses as appropriate.
@Caleb Cartwright @Daniel Silverstone yeah i think y'all should be teams, that decision predates me and I don't think it makes sense anymore

i gather there's really two aspects then, whether rustup & rustfmt should be teams instead of wgs, and then what, if any impact, there is on a "collective of maintainers" having one classification vs another.

sounds like an overwhelming consensus of yes on the former, while there's some differing perspectives on the latter. i think that's reasonable and not unexpected; in the case of missed comms, those that have received those communications may not be as concerned based on what they've received whereas those that haven't may be in the uneasy "don't know what i don't know" posture.

my only thought is that if certain parties, e.g. the Foundation, are attempting to communicate to the entire project then i want to make sure i receive those comms, even if that also comes paired with loads of spam. i've not really thought about it beyond devtools, but obviously there could be other wgs and or project groups that could be in a similar boat :shrug:
yeah i think y'all def should be in those lists
